content: As already mentioned below, the proper word is not "shifting", it's generally "rotating" (or maybe "circular shifting" if your prefer). See for instance Ruby where both methods exist: https://ruby-doc.org/core-2.7.1/Array.html

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle for speedy clashes. Well done.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A pretty interesting puzzle. Not too hard, but not too easy either.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Will be cool tp play

Hi,
I really do like this clash, able to solve it within 1min30 in javascript, 
Definitly perfect for fastest and shortest code but i disagree making it a reverse one ...

As mentionned by luke-guyton, you should constraint [[pos]] like 
0 < [[pos]] < [[any max here]] => don't limit to N , up to gamers to mod id for code efficiency.

Remove Reverse & add contraint and i'll approve

Regards

Is there a maximum shift?
Consider rewriting the constraint:
0 < [[pos]] < [[N]]

May I suggest that the "Left" / "Right" line is moved to the top? that allows programmers in some languages to more easily parse the remaining integers, giving some efficiencies for shortest for example.

Hi, if I left shift a byte, the leftmost bits fall off; similarly right shift / rightmost.
Perhaps instead of "shift" you mean "rotate"?

Your stub input is incorrect: it generates code which expects the integers on separate lines.
To fix this, change "loop N read temp:int" to "loopline N temp:int"

Constraints:
"3 >= N" should be "3 <= N"

direction = {"Left", "Right"} suggests that direction is a dictionary(?) containing "Left" and "Right". I would change this to just:
direction is "Left" or "Right"

I would specify whether pos can be negative, or zero:
pos >= 0, or pos > 0

Goal "You must shift a sequence of integers several positions to the left or to the right":
"several positions" is not true if pos == 1
I'd suggest
"You must shift a sequence of integers a number of positions to the left or to the right"
or just
"You must shift a sequence of integers to the left or to the right"

I would include test cases for:
pos > N
pos == 0
No, there is not. There are actually two test cases when pos > N
